title: 109_s2695
content: The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 aims to make research funded by the Federal Government accessible to the public. Congress recognizes the importance of sharing research findings to advance science and benefit society. The Act defines a "Federal agency" as an Executive agency under title 5, United States Code. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 requires Federal agencies with over $100,000,000 in research expenditures to develop a policy for public access to research papers. This policy includes submitting final manuscripts of research papers to the agency, incorporating peer review changes, and replacing the manuscript with the published version. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 mandates Federal agencies to provide free online public access to final peer-reviewed manuscripts or published versions within 6 months of publication, create an online bibliography linking to full texts, and preserve research findings in a digital repository for long-term access. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 requires Federal agencies to ensure free public access to research works in approved repositories, with conditions like interoperability and long-term preservation. Researchers employed or funded by the agency must mark public domain works as such and make them immediately available online. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 mandates Federal agencies to provide free public access to research works in approved repositories, with conditions like interoperability and long-term preservation. The policy excludes certain materials like laboratory notes, preliminary data analyses, and works generating revenue for authors. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 requires Federal agencies to submit an annual report on their public access policy to specific Congressional committees. The report must assess the effectiveness of the policy in providing public access to research works. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 mandates Federal agencies to provide free online access to research papers funded by the agency. This includes lists of papers published in peer-reviewed journals, papers available through the agency's public access policy, and timeframes for paper availability. Federal agencies must make research papers funded by the agency available to the public by posting statements and lists on their website.
